text: The following conversation takes place over BLACK or CRED
Hello?
Hey Brie?
Yeah?
It's Luke.
Hi Luke.
What's going on?
Um, I'm actually putting away some groceries I just got.
Oh yeah?
Yeah.
What'd you get?
Um. Are you serious, do you want me to tell you?
No, I guess not. Unless it's, like, a ton of cat food and you don’t have a cat.
Actually I have fifteen cats.
Well, that's weird.
Now you know.
So, did you still want to hang out tonight?
Yeah, but I have to meet up with some friends later on so do you mind if we meet kind of early?
Sure, what time were you thinking?
Do you want to meet at seven?
No.
No?
I'm just kidding, seven is fine.
Is that enough time for you to get ready? I'm sure that bed head takes at least thirty minutes to get into place.
So this is how it's gonna be, is it? Brie laughs.
You scared? You want to call the whole thing off?
No, no. So I'll see you at seven at The Scene, right?
Yeah.
Sounds good.
Okay. See you there.
Okay. Bye.
Bye.
A series of shots show the areas of L.A. County winding d from a hard days work. It’s a typical, beautiful evening.
LUKE PUTNAM (25) drives down Santa Monica Blvd. listening music. He checks his reflection one more time in the rear view mirror.
Luke drives by the bar slowly, looking out the window for sign of Brie outside. None.
Luke walks up to the front of the bar and looks around. After a minute of looking he pulls out his phone and dial number.
Hello?
Colin. Hey.
Hey Luke, what’s up?
Not much.
Are you on your date?
Actually, I’m waiting outside. We're supposed to meet at seven. (MORE )
I’m just calling because I felt like a tool just standing here waiting for her.
Right. Understood. Isn’t seven a little early?

Yeah, I thought so. She said she wanted to get together early because she has to meet up with her friends later. I don’t know if maybe she was giving herself an out just in case or if it’s true, but I said whatever.
Definitely sounds like an out.
Yeah. Hopefully she won't use it. Luke turns and looks around again.
What’s her name again?
Brie, like the cheese. And actually, I think I see her car.
Oh, okay.
Wait. Just hang on the line a second.
Okay. Luke tries to look in the door as someone leaves.
I'm watching this video on YouTube and.
Alright, I’1l talk to you later man.
Okay, have fun.  Luke closes the flap on his phone bouncer.
Got your I.D.?
Yeah. Luke pulls out his wallet and I.D. Bouncer.
Alright man, have fun.
Thanks.

and heads over to the and shows it to the Luke walks into the bar and sees Brie sitting at a corner table with three guys. One of them is SCOTT (28), who tur and looks behind him. Luke points at him and his expression reads “You?” Scott acknowledges and turns to Brie. scott This is the guy you’re waiting for?
Yeah. Luke gets to the table and extends a hand to shake.
What’s up Scott?
You know him?
Yeah. sScoTtT We worked together.
Where? At our office?
Yeah, Scott’s one of the editors.  One of the other guys at the table, JOSH (30) chimes in.
What’s going on? scoTtT Sit down, sit down.
Uh, I’m gonna get a drink. You- Luke points at Brie but realizes she has a drink in front her.
-are good. Okay. I’11 be back. Luke heads over to the bar. sScoTtT That's really weird.
Yeah, I work at the reception desk. scoTtT Really? Which floor? I’ve never seen you.
Look harder buddy. I’m there.
The bartender is in the middle of telling Luke that they’ out of the beer he wants.
No, we don’t have it.
Really? Okay, can I get a Coors Light? The bartender pours a draft while Luke looks around some more.
That’s four. Luke hands him a debit card. BARTENDER (CONT’D) You want to start a tab?
Yeah, please. Luke grabs his drink and heads off.

Luke makes his way over to sit next to Brie, which puts h slightly and awkwardly out of the circle of conversation. Scott turns to him. scoTtT Hey sorry, this is Josh and this is Darrell. Josh and Darrell both give nods or small waves.
Hey, what’s up? Brie turns to Luke and finally exchanges a personal greet
Hi.
Hi. How’s it going?
Good.
What are you drinking?
A little whiskey.
Nice.
How about you?
Uh, Coors Light. The Silver Bullet.
Fancy.
Yeah. So you don’t know these guys?  Suddenly Luke notices that no one at the table has been talking. It’s just him and Brie while the rest of the guy sit, arms folded, small smiles on their faces.
No, I just said hello while I was waiting for you. Isn’t that weird?
Yeah.
I got here a little early and I didn’t want to do that thing where you just get out your cell phone and talk to someone so you don’t look stupid so I just came in to get a drink and said hello.
Wow. Scott angles back in. sScoTtT So, Darrell here is getting married.
Really?
Yeah.
Congratulations! That’s great.
Is it?
Of course it is.
Thanks. sScoTtT We're trying to talk him out of it. He’s only been dating her for three months.
Wow.
Don’t listen to them.
Three months! It’s like, a season. scoTtT (to Brie mostly) You want to know why I think he’s getting married? Luke takes a sip of beer.
It’s not true.
It is. sScoTtT It’s because he’s going bald.
Why would you tell them that? sScoTtT That's why he’s wearing that cap.
So what if he’s going bald? sScoTtT Because he’s worried that when he goes bald he’s not going to be able to land any other girls.
What?
It’s not true.
(a la “Seinfeld”) He’s BALD! sScoTtT Take off your hat.
There’s plenty of bald guys that get laid.
Not with hot girls.
I’m sure I’ve seen some bald guys with attractive girls. sScoTtT Would you date a bald guy?
Me? I don’t know. scoTtT (answering for her) No.
Maybe! It depends!
Come on.
Look, flowing locks is the not the only quality I look for in a man but I mean, I prefer hair. I can admit that. sScoTtT Everybody prefers hair.
But true love is hair-blind. sScoTtT Hair-blind?
Yeah. sScoTtT But you gotta get the girl to fall in love with you first and that’s much harder to do if you're bald.
I think you are underestimating most girls.  11.
Girls are stupid. Brie bristles visibly.
What? Brie’s stare is cold as ice. Darrell and Scott pick up on but Josh doesn’t.
Look, this is one big conversation that doesn’t need to be happening because I’m not going bald.
(not budging) Why are girls stupid? sScoTtT Josh is stupid, don’t worry about it.
I’m just saying. Luke touches the sleeve of Brie’s jacket.
I like this jacket.
Thanks. Brie barely registers the compliment. Instead her whole demeanor changes and she slouches back into her seat. sScoTtT Dude Luke, you bailed just in time. The office is getting insane.
Really? sScoTtT Mark just started losing his mind for no apparent reason and the work load has totally doubled.
That sucks.  12. sScoTtT Have you found a new job yet?
Nope. Not really looking for one. scoTtT Nice. Living the dream.
What do you do?
I was an assistant. Like an intern at his office.
(to Brie) And you work there too?
Yep.
Crazy.
Hey. Hey. I’m sorry I forgot your name.
Brie.
Sorry. Brie, like the cheese. I’1ll remember that.. Let me ask you something.
Dude wait. You know who else is named after cheese and is amazing?
Who?
Monterey Jack from Chip ‘n’ Dale Rescue Rangers. Scott laughs.  13.
Right?! Whenever he smelled cheese he would just start floating toward it like a zeppelin. Amazing.
A zeppelin?
Yeah.
Dude stop, I have a serious question.
Okay. . .

I’m getting married in four months and we have a date set and everything. And so now my fiancee wants to stop having sex from now until the wedding so it can feel kind of like having sex for the first time again on the wedding night.
Okay.
Isn't that stupid?
That’s the question?
I mean, is this a female thing? Am I crazy or does it not make any sense?
I don’t know. It doesn’t make sense to me, but if she feels strongly about it and it makes sense to her then you should probably just do it.
We had sex on the first night we met.  scoTtT He tells this to everyone when he first meets them.
So it’s like, what’s the point?
Like I said, I don’t know. I gave a guy a handjob at an assembly in ninth grade but some people are just weird about sex. Luke’s eyes visibly widen as he takes a big sip of beer.
Wow.
She probably just feels guilty. Is she religious or her parents, are they really religious?
Not really. sScoTtT Wait, so could other kids see you giving him the handjob in the assembly?
No, he put his backpack on his lap or something. It was discreet.
Dude, tell them what happened.
What happened what?
When you met her parents.
No. Stop interrupting! Scott bursts out laughing. Luke and Brie are lost. scoTtT It’s brilliant.
Tell the fucking story!
Shut up.
I'm telling it.
God damn you guys. Scott continues laughing. Luke is almost done with his beer.
So Darrell went and spent the weekend with his girlfriend's parents last week. They live in Michigan.
Is this an embarrassing meet the parents story? sScoTtT Big time.
He was in Michigan and his girlfriend's parents took everyone out for an engagement party kind of deal and this guy gets hammered. Just fucking stone cold drunk.
Everybody was buying me shots.
So they go back to the house late that night and him and his girlfriend try to have sex.
What? What do you mean try?
You said you fell asleep like three minutes into it. scott Three minutes into it is two minutes after it’s over.  16.
Yeah, I fell asleep but we had sex for a little bit first.
Whatever, so they fall asleep naked and he wakes up at like 4 am feeling like he’s gonna barf.
It was inevitable.
He stumbles to the bathroom, still naked and pukes like six times.
This story is fucking gross so far.

Hang on, hang on. So, he finishes up and stumbles back into the bedroom, climbs back into bed and falls asleep. It’s not until the next morning does anybody realize that he had gone back into the wrong room and climbed naked into bed with his girlfriend’s brother.
My future brother-in-law. Brie laughs. Scott is cracking up too.
That’s not true.
It’s totally fucking true.
That kind of shit doesn’t happen to people.
I wish it didn’t but it did. sScoTtT Amazing.
Was he mad?  17.
He took it pretty well. He was cool. It wasn’t as damaging as it could have been.
Wow.
I know, I know. Believe me, I thought that stuff only happened in John Hughes movies, but no.
John Hughes?
Yeah, there’s a scene like that in Planes, Trains and Automobiles.
I haven't seen it.
“Those aren’t pillows!”
It’s good. Luke is finished with his beer and sees a break in the conversation.
(to Brie) You want another drink? Brie looks at her drink- just a few sips left.
Actually, I should probably get going to meet my friends. Luke looks a little frustrated.
Oh yeah?

Yeah.  18. sScoTtT The best part of that movie is when John Candy turns into the devil for like three seconds when they are stuck in between the two trucks. Like, for no reason, he has a devil costume on for three seconds and he’s screaming.
(to Luke) I’m gonna have a cigarette though, do you want one?
Uh, sure.
Okay.
Luke and Brie stand outside the bar on the corner. Brie pulls a pack of American Spirits out of her purse and han one to Luke. He twiddles it around his fingers while she pulls one out herself.
Hang on. Brie approaches a SMOKER standing next to them. BRIE (CONT’D) Excuse me, do you have a light?
Yeah. Smoker pulls a Zippo out of his pocket and lights it for Brie. She dangles her cigarette in and takes a puff.
Thanks. Brie comes back over to Luke and offers him her smoke.
Here.  19.
Thanks. How come you have cigarettes but no lighter?
It’s a way of trying to quit. Cut down at least.
Does it work?
Does it look like it’s working? Luke lights his cigarette with hers and hands it back.
So you gotta go huh?
Yeah, I think so. My friends are kind of waiting for me.
That’s cool.
I can’t believe you know those guys.
I don’t know all those guys, just Scott. We just worked together. But now we don’t.
So, this was your first week of unemployment, right?
Yeah, I’m on day three.
But you’ve got a plan.
I’m working on a piece that I pitched to the Times.
The New York Times? Jesus. You didn’t tell me that.  20.
The L.A. Times.
Oh. That’s cool too.
Well, they have this kind of long- winded editorial process so I’m getting bounced around a little bit. But they’re giving me time, which is nice.
That is nice of them. You've got enough money to make it last?
That’s the plan. I took out a loan from the bank. (beat) I figure it’s like going back to school but I get to spend the money the way I want.
That's pretty smart. How much did you get?
They gave me a loan for five thousand dollars.
That’s it?
I’m eating sandwiches. Brie raises her eyebrows.
I would have asked for ten. If you’re gonna go, go all the way.
Well I’m just more frugal than you are.
Or less daring.  21.
I always thought it would be funny to do a spoof show of “The Fraggles”, you know that show?
Of course.

But have it be “The Frugals” instead and it’s just a bunch of tight wad investors and bankers living underground being like “You spent how much on socks!?” Brie chuckles. Luke is pleased. They take a drag.
How about you? How’ve you been?
Uh, fine. Work is boring and stressful.
Yeah but that building would collapse if you weren't there.
Ha, right. And that’s the only reason I’m still there. To hold that building up.
Well, what else would you be doing?
I mean, I don’t know. I guess I can’t complain. It’s a safe job and I’m making money. The money’s not the problem, you know?
Yeah, totally.
Yeah, for Christmas last year I bought my mom her first pair of really expensive shoes. Not her first pair- you know.  22.
How expensive?

Just- expensive. They don’t have them where she lives. I don’t even think she knew they existed. I mean, she used to be this fashion maven but she’s starting to lag a bit in her old age. So, I gotta pick up her slack.
I know what you mean. I won a game show and-
Wait, you won a game show?
Yeah.
Which one?
You haven't heard of it.
How do you know?
Nobody's heard of it.
Come on, what is it?
It’s called On the Cover.
What the hell is On the Cover?
See?
What is it?  23.
It’s just. They show you a fake magazine cover of like, People Magazine with Denzel Washington's picture on it and you have to name who’s “on the cover”.
That’s it?
Yeah.
Sounds easy.
It is.
And retarded.
Have you ever done it? It’s tough getting that buzzer to work before anyone else's.
Okay, okay. I’m sorry. But you won, right?
Yeah.
How much money?
Ten thousand bucks.
Ten thousand bucks!? For a little game show no one has heard of?
Yeah, so that Christmas was the first time I could ever afford to get everyone in my family cool presents.
Jesus Christ.  24.
I’m usually the guy that gives everyone a CD or a book, but I actually got some cool gifts that year.
Loans and game shows, no wonder you don’t need a job.
Exactly.
How much do you have left?
Why, you gonna order more expensive drinks?
Maybe.
None.
Come on.
Really, none. I bought a car. Not a new one or anything. A used one, but I bought it straight up. Caaash.
So you're broke again?
Broke is a strong word. No, I got the loan. I got some savings. And I have a car.
I could totally win that show.
I don’t know if it’s still on the air. They pause and smoke their cigarettes.  25.
I’d do really well at Jeopardy. It’s all proper names and places and one or two-word responses and I’m good at that stuff.
Okay, what's the capitol of Cyprus?
Cyprus? Greece?
Sure.
Nicosia.
Really?
Look it up. I remember it because it’s spelled close to Nicoise salad. Mnemonically.
I’m impressed. Most people something about Cyprus on the news and think it’s like, a made-up country.

But Jeopardy. Or Presidents! I know a shit-ton about presidents. Half the stuff on Jeopardy is presidential facts, so I wouldn't even have to study that. Luke smokes, doesn’t really inhale. Brie catches this, bu says nothing.
I'd win and I'd use the money to buy my mom a house. A beach house. Out near Rockport or somewhere maybe a little less uppity.
Moms love beach houses.  26.
It was really nice getting a solid gift for my mother. Even if it was just shoes.
What did your dad get?
Dad got a tie. It’s what he likes.

My mom asked me to make her a mix last year. She wanted to know what I was listening to. I put some songs on a CD for her and gave it to her. I made her a mixtape. I put “2 Minutes to Midnight” by Iron Maiden as a hidden bonus track at the end and she wasn’t nearly as amused about that as I was.
I don’t know that one.

(sings but trails off mid- way ) “2 Minutes to Midnight!!!!" Brie nods and looks around. A girl clacks outside on her heels. She pulls up next to Brie. Her name is STACY and she talks loudly into her cel phone.
I don’t care what he eats. It bores me. (beat) Did she hit you? Did she hit him? Brie and Luke listen as Brie finishes her cigarette.

It doesn’t matter that he’s from South America. People aren’t any different down there. They follow the same rules as the rest of the world. (beat) There’s meat. And then there’s grass.  27. Luke catches Brie’s eye. He makes a face. She makes one b
And that’s what you’ve gotta tell them. (beat) Hold on a second. (turns to Brie; sotto voce) Can I have one of those, I’m so sorry? Brie, smiling, hands one over.
Thank you. (back into phone) No, I’m sorry, I was talking to someone. Brie steps her cigarette out. She notices Luke has almost half of his left.
Slow smoker.
Savor it, that’s what I say.
You don’t smoke do you? Luke inhales a drag and blows the smoke out confidently, if that answers the question.

Sometimes. They look around at the few other people standing outside few feet away stand a GUY and a GIRL seemingly not very h with each other. The guy holds his phone out and is texting away. The girl looks at him with disgust. After a moment and in one fell swoop she SWATS the phone of his hands and it BOUNCES on the concrete.
Jesus Christ! Luke and Brie look at each other with wide eyes.  28.
Yikes.
I think there’s gonna be a fight.
I think so too. They look again but the couple have wandered off up the street.
Have you ever been in a fight?
No. Have you?
Yeah. In eighth grade. Everybody was picking fights and it was like, the cool thing. So I picked the smallest, weakest guy in the class and I made him fight me.
What a jerk!
I know. His name was Dawson Mullen and he was from Canada.
Poor Dawson Mullen. Brie gets out another cigarette to smoke.
Our high school was right next to this movie theatre called the Bijou. When you wanted to pick a fight with someone, you went up to them and said ‘Bijou parking lot. Two Thirty.’
That was the call out? Still listening, Brie bums another light off of someone.  29.
Yeah. The thrown gauntlet. Bijou parking lot was where all the real shit went down. Pot smoking. All that.
I guess my friend Lauren’s house would be our Bijou parking lot equivalent because that’s where we always did the bad stuff.

So. There were a bunch of kids all waiting on the grassy side of this movie theatre. And they form this big circle and we get in the middle. And Dawson is like “Come on, start something. Start something.” So I pushed him and he just clocks me in the face. Out of nowhere.
Ha!
I didn’t fall over or anything but man, it hurt. And I guess normal people get angry when they get punched in the face but I just kind of realized that fighting was dumb.
Aww, poor little pacifist.
He sort of knocked some sense into me. So, that was the end of the fight.
You lost in one punch?
I forfeited.
I kind of had a fight once. This girl was really pissing me off in tenth grade. She thought I was flirting with her boyfriend or something, which I probably was. (MORE )

But she tried to start something in the cafeteria. And she was Puerto Rican so the whole lunch room split into whites versus Puerto Ricans for the fight that never actually happened. It was like the Jets versus the Sharks.
Huh.
West Side Story reference. Don’t worry if you don’t get it, I’m the nerd, not you.
I was in West Side Story.
Really? Who’d you play?
(thinks) Like, Jet Boy number four. Brie laughs.
That’s hilarious.

I remember we had to give ourselves names on these character sheets, to make you feel like you were really “acting.” And so I turned mine in with the name “Davey”. But my friends all turned in these cool names like “Action” and “One Punch”. And I was stuck with “Davey”.

I had to do the same thing when I was a pink lady in “Grease”. We had those sheets too. You had to fill in all this unnecessary information like what our favorite ice cream flavor and stuff was. So dumb.
Can I have another one of those?  31. Brie hands Luke another cigarette and he lights it with h

My high school did this Shakespeare play called “The Merry Wives of Windsor”. I wasn’t in it but I saw it, and there’s a scene where two guys are talking to each other. And they’re talking about something, but I guess they forget their lines because there’s just this sudden silence: like, fifteen seconds of nothing. Then one guy turns to the other and says “So, how ‘bout the Bulls?”
No.

Swear to God. And this is during the playoffs, so the other guy’s like: “Repeat the three-peat!” So they talk about the Bulls for a good two minutes. I guess someone was supposed to enter and they didn’t or something, but then the three-peat guy just got up and started doing the worm.
Oh my god.
The audience loved it. They all cheered when he did the worm. In the middle of “The Merry Wives of Windsor”.
That’s hilarious.
That’s Tennessee.
I saw a production of “West Side Story” that was like, the traveling Broadway production. And you know how in the end, Chino is supposed to run out on stage with the gun and shoot Tony?  32.
Yeah.

Well I guess the guy playing Chino forgot the gun because he runs out on the stage. Pauses for a second. Then takes off his shoe and yells “Poison boot!” and throws it at Tony. Luke laughs. BRIE (CONT’D) And it hits him in the chest and he just looks at it for a second and then falls over.
Poison boot?
Best improv ever. But the best part is that the scene has to continue and Maria has to pick up the shoe and be like “How much poison is left in this boot, Chino? Enough for you? Enough for me?”
That’s worse than the worm.
Way worse.
Do you still do any theater?
No. I got over that.
Yeah, me too. My swansong was the Head Flying Monkey in “The Wiz”.
“The Wizard of Oz"?
No, no. “The Wiz”.
Really?  33.

Oh yeah. Public school’s are all about color blind casting. We had white people trying to sing soul in “The Wiz”, we did “The Sound of Music” with three white and two Filipino Von Trapp kids. And we even had black Nazis in “The Sound of Music”.
Wow.
Jesus. I haven’t thought about this stuff in a long time. It is absurd.
I love it. I love High School stuff. They are finished with their cigarettes.
You want to go back inside?
Yeah. They turn to head back into the bar and are met at the doorway by Scott, Darrell and Josh heading out. scoTtrT Hey, we're heading to that other bar if you guys want to come.
Umm. I think we’re gonna hang out here a bit more. sScoTtT Okay. Come to Saddle Ranch on Sunset if you change your mind.
Okay. See you.
Nice meeting you.
Luke stands at the bar ordering two more drinks.
The sun has set and the night takes over the city. It’s a cool, calm evening all across Los Angeles.
Brie and Luke stand by the wall of the bar, drinking and talking.
You work with kids, right?
Yeah, I do. I work with middle and elementary school kids. Volunteer work, mostly.
I didn’t know you were a teacher.

We do mostly after school stuff and there’s workshops that we have during the day. Kids from all these schools around Venice take field trips to come see us, so they’re usually pretty happy to be somewhere else.
What do you work-shop with ten year- olds?

Well, one of them, my favorite actually, is a storytelling workshop. They come in and the idea is to get them to write a story as a group. I help them through. This is pretty fun, actually. We have a computer that projects up onto the wall so you can see what’s being typed.
Sounds like a big operation.  35.

It's pretty big. It’s me and five other people. Got a typist, an illustrator who draws on this pad that’s connected to another computer, but here’s the best part. There’s a cranky editor named Mr. Crabtree who lives in the attic, and occasionally he'll come in over this intercom. He’s like: “Where's my stories! I'm trying to run a publishing company here! I need fifteen stories by twelve o'clock or Brie's going to lose her job!"
The kids respond to pressure like that?

Yeah. It’s just another one of the volunteers in the office talking in a grumpy voice through a baby monitor. They get a kick out of it. They kind of freeze up, but then after awhile, after the editor comes back on and yells at them a little bit more, they get wise. They usually spend most of the workshop trying to figure out which one of us is the voice from the attic.
And what exactly do you do?

They come in and I ‘conduct’ them. All on the floor sitting in a circle, like fourteen or eighteen kids. I ask them, what’s the first thing you need to write a story? Luke waits. Brie nods at him to answer the question.
Oh, a title.
No. The title comes last. You can’t get married to a title early on.
A main character?  36.
Exactly. I ask them what their favorite animal is, and we usually go from there. Sometimes it’s pirates or astronauts, but animals always do well in a pinch.
You've gotta make sure there’s a boy and a girl, right?
Gotta have both. If there’s more girls in the class, the main character becomes a girl squid or a girl construction worker. Same thing if it’s more boys.
How long does it take.
Two hours. We all write the story together and then the kids have to go and finish up their specific end to the story.
So you get fifteen stories with all different endings?
For the most part. You'd be surprised how many of their endings are the same. We try to push them to be more inventive, but the kids are of the same mind about things, without even knowing it.
So they all end with the girl squid and the boy pirate living happily ever after?
You got a better ending?
No. I wish those two all the best. They deserve it. The conversation lulls. Different CHARACTERS from the bar take over.  11 37. ADAM and MARINA are talking at a table.
Delilah.
That’s a great middle name.
I love it. I’m going to name my daughter Delilah.
Did you grow up religious?
Hunh? No.
You know there’s major religious overtones with a name like that.
Really?
Samson and Delilah? You don’t know that story? She’s the one who cut off all his hair when he was asleep.
She did what?
Samson was the strongest man in the city. And Delilah cut off his hair with a pair of golden scissors. She took his strength by cutting off his hair.
What book is that from? Adam is incredulous.
The bible?
CHAS and DAPHNE sit at a table. Chas is wasted and scribb on a bar napkin.  12 38.
Fifteen to ten! Daphne sips at her drink. Looks horrified.
That's only five more points! Daphne gets up, puts a napkin over her drink, and exits frame. Chas sits alone. Eventually, he will go to the bathroom and insult Luke’s penis.
LEMUEL and NAN talking about the tissue bank she works at
You got a prostate?
Yesterday. A piece of one.
Is it like hamburger?
It’s not cooked.
What’s it like though? How big is it?
Looks like...fibrous...I think it had a tumor. It was hard.
You touched it?
One was a tumor and one wasn’t. With the forceps.
Poke me where you think it feels like. Nan pokes his arm in a couple of places.
Kind a like that. Lemuel pokes his own arm.  13 39. (CONT'D)
Raw steak. Kind of. Maybe like a chicken steak.
You're not a vegetarian, are you?
Most of the time. No cows.

head_text.subj: BACK AT LUKE AND BRIE- LATER 13

text: Still sitting, Brie unloads her purse onto the table. She produces a phone from deep inside its guts.
We should call Leslie. Luke holds a hand over his right eye like an eye-patch.
Leslie? Brie punches him.
Yes.
Why?
Because she’s on a first date.
Oh really?
Yeah, she’s on a date with Average Man. Have you met him?
I don’t think so.
He’s on the fifth floor. He’s a lawyer. He’s nice and everything but he’s totally ordinary so Leslie and I call him Average Man.
That doesn’t sound very good.  14 40.
We should see if he becomes Above Average Man on a date.
Okay. Brie gets out her phone and dials. Luke takes a sip of hi beer and looks around.

Hey Leslie. . . How’s your date? . . . Really? I assumed it was gonna be bad since you picked up... That's good. . . Is he buying you average priced drinks? . . . Nice. Luke stretches and works on his beer.

Is he right there? . . . Okay, I’1l just ask yes and no questions. . . Does he have man boobs?. . . Can you see them? Brie is amusing herself. BRIE (CONT’D) Has he mentioned his car more than two times already? . . . Are you gonna make him double bag it? Brie looks at Luke but doesn’t make any indication of try to wrap it up. Luke mimes out “I’m going to the bathroom”. Brie nods.
Luke walks into the bathroom and up to the only available urinal out of two. Next to him stands CHAS.
Hey.
Hey. Luke begins to pee.  15 41.
Nice cock.
What?
Just kidding. Chas zips up his pants and leaves the bathroom without washing his hands. Luke stands by himself, peeing. Running through the eveni in his mind.
Brie is still talking on the phone.

I’m hanging out with Luke. . . He worked for the magazine. . . Yes you do, he’s the “Supplies!” guy. . . I know. . . Yeah, it’s fine. Whatever. Luke comes back and sits down. BRIE (CONT’D) Okay. I’11 talk to you later. Bye. Brie hangs up the phone and puts it back into her purse.
Sorry.
Sure. How is she?
Good. She says Average Man is a gentleman.
That’s good. Is he older?
Not like way older but yeah.
Well, go Average Man, go!  16 talking to each other.
I’m kind of hungry. Are you hungry?
Yeah I could eat.
Where can we go?
There’s a pizza place nearby. up the street I think.
Is it good?
Just Yeah. I mean, it’s pizza but it’s good.
Pizza sounds amazing.
Let’s do it.
O-kay.

Brie reaches over and downs the last sip of Luke’s beer. 16 Luke and Brie step outside of the bar to find a small gathering of people out smoking or talking. I’m not exactly sure which way it is. Luke walks over to them.
Hey man, where is that place? Luke looks around and sees two guys, TALON and SPENCER Talon is holding a TO-GO PIZZA BOX Talon looks up and realizes Luke means the pizza.
It’s right down the street there. Why, you want pizza?
Yeah, I think we’re gonna get a slice.
Dude, you can have some of this, we can’t eat it all. 43. Talon opens up the box to show a pristine Hawaiian Pizza.
Oh thanks but I think we’re gonna get our own.
Seriously man, we can’t eat it all.
No thanks. Spencer leans in and adds-
Dude, we can’t eat it all.
Come on. Eat it. It’s Hawaiian. Luke looks to Brie, who shrugs.
Okay.
Thanks. Luke and Brie reach in and grab a slice each. Talon out his free hand.
I’m Talon. This is Spencer. Everyone shakes.
Nice to meet you. I’m Brie.
Luke. reaches
Cool. Dig in.
You're sure you don’t mind?
Dude, we can’t eat it all.
(to Luke) What do you do?
Um, nothing at the moment.
Really? Nothing?
Yeah. Brie and Spencer begin their own conversation.
Where are you from Spencer?
Virginia Beach.
Really? Is that nice?
I guess. Missy Elliott is from there too. While Talon talks to Luke, he tries to keep one ear on Spencer and Brie’s conversation.
That’s cool. Have you ever heard of Fulbright & Lewis?
Is that the sofa company?
No, it’s a law firm. It’s the law firm I work for.
Oh cool.  17 45.
Yeah, they represent a lot of celebrities, big civil cases. Like Denzel Washington was just in our office.
They let you have that beard?
They let me do whatever the fuck I want. I’m a genius. (beat) Are you guys going inside?
Uh.
Come on, you guys need a drink. I’m buying.
(to Talon) You owe me like, two thousand dollars.
Okay.
Talon continues to tell Luke about his job while Spencer Brie talk about something else. Two SUPER HOT GIRLS come up with their eyes on the pizza
Hey. You guys have pizza? Spencer and Talon immediately shift their focus to these friends.
Yeah dude, have a slice. Luke looks at Brie and they silently agree to make a brea for it. They slip off while the guys are distracted.
Those guys were nice.  46.
Yeah, you want to play pool?
I’m terrible.
Good. I’11 win then. They make their way towards the pool table. Luke puts some money in and racks the pool balls over the following:
Actually those guys remind me of these models I used to live with.
Those guys?
Yeah. Just the way they talked and acted. I don’t know, the demeanor.
You lived with models?

Mmm hmm. It was what I like to refer to as a ‘quick-change’ atmosphere. It’s like theatre, always changing outfits. Changing zip codes, changing drugs. Changing the people you’re friends with. Everything. You go out to bars in Beverly Hills and all the drinks are paid for. It’s an interesting way to live your life.
Living through the kindness of others.
I don’t know if ‘kindness’ is the word I'd use. Luke breaks. He pauses. Considers the table.
What do you think about that?  47.
About what?
About the fact that men are supposed to buy the drinks? Don’t you think they’re only buying drinks to get you drunk?
And not for the actual enjoyment of buying someone a drink?
Yeah. Brie holds up her drink.
Are you trying to get me drunk?
No, but pizza guys might be.
Listen. That’s the way it is. I don’t mind some churlish guy buying me a couple of vodka sodas. I don’t have to go home with him. There’s no contract I’m aware of. There’s no body promise.
Isn't that patronizing?
I don’t think about people patronizing me. It’s just a social structure. A way of doing things that’s accepted. ‘A’ leads to ‘B.’
So ‘A’ is the initial contact?
Sure. Then ‘B’ is the next drink or the conversation or whatever comes next.
What happens when you get to ‘C’?  48.
Well, if ‘C’ means me taking my shirt off and barreling down on some guy in the middle of the bar...There doesn’t have to be a ‘C’. The ball is in my court.
What if you make the initial contact? Then by the time it gets to ‘C’, the ball is in their court.
No. Wrong. When it gets to ‘C’, the ball is never in the guy’s court.
Oh really?
Never. But here’s where the theory fails: Marriage.
Huh?
Getting married...
Wait, backtrack a second. How often do you barrel down on some guy in the middle of the bar?

Fuck off. Get your mind out of the gutter. How would you like it if girls were always buying you drinks and staring at your boobs while you tried to have a conversation with them? This startles Luke. He can’t help but glance down at Brie boobs. BRIE (CONT’D) You just looked at my boobs.
I know! You said the word “boobs” and it just happened. Sorry.  49.
Well, see?
I apologize.

Think about every girl you know. What if every relationship you had with a member of the opposite sex was based on the assumption that they would fuck you if they got the chance? Like, every time some guy said he wanted to get a drink with you or go for a walk, that that guy is actually thinking: maybe I'll have a chance with her tonight. Maybe tonight will be the night she gets drunk and wants to fuck me.
That’s pretty dire.
It is pretty fucking dire, if you wanna know the truth. But wait: marriage. Have you ever heard about the Coolidge effect?
No.
Calvin Coolidge. Thirtieth president of the United States. 1923 to... (thinks) 1930.
Bullshit.
I told you. I’m not fucking around with my presidential knowledge.
Jeopardy’s gonna call you any day.
But, so. Calvin Coolidge and his wife...Grace...are taking separate tours of a farm somewhere. (MORE )

Mrs. Coolidge is walking along and she sees all these hens hopping around and pecking at things and Mrs. Coolidge says, “Man, that’s a lot of hens. That’s a lot of work for one old rooster.” The tour guide says, “He’s fine, ma’am. The rooster works very hard.” Then Mrs. Coolidge says, “Really? He's working hard every day?” “Oh sure”, says the man. “Dozens of times a day”. “Interesting!” says Mrs. Coolidge. “You be sure to tell that to the President!” Brie catches a breath. BRIE (CONT’D) So later, Coolidge is walking along with the same tour guide and he passes the hens. The tour guide tells him with Mrs. Coolidge said. “Same hen every time?” he asks. “Well, no”, says the guide. “It’s a different one every time.” Coolidge leans in to the guide and smirks and says, “You tell that to Mrs. Coolidge.”
There’s a moral to this story.
There is. And it’s that men are hard-wired to spread their seed as often as possible with as many different partners as possible.
Well, it makes sense, from an evolutionary standpoint.

No, it’s bullshit! They do these experiments where they put one male rat in a cage with ten female rats and he fucks them all like crazy. But then he gets tired and just sleeps in the corner and the female rats will nudge him and lick him and stuff but he’s just not into it anymore. Until they put a new female in the mix and then all of a sudden he’s horny as hell again.  18 19 20 51.
Really?

And they say that’s the Coolidge Effect but really, they’ve done the same thing with female rats and they have the same reaction. It’s not just a male thing. The real moral is everybody gets tired of fucking the same person after a while.
City life continues while Luke and Brie are cooped up ins

Luke and Brie are taking turns getting their picture take Luke hops in, then Brie, then Luke again. He waits to see Brie will hop in for the last photo, but she doesn’t. He’ left sitting there with an expectant look on his face.
Luke and Brie wait for the photos to come out.
You didn’t play anything?
I played tennis in high school.
Not a good experience?

No. It was fine. My friends all played field hockey and I didn’t feel like getting pummeled with sticks. This girl I knew named Sarah Neaves, she was always showing up in the mornings with a black eye.
Poor Sarah Neaves.  52.
Yeah. She was really athletic though. All the guys called her Steve Neaves.
Oh my god. I’m surprised they had the nerve, those field hockey girls will fuck you up.
Did you have a run in with a field hockey player?
I dated one.
That counts.
Yeah. My first girlfriend played field hockey for the rival high school. I used to go to her games.
How old were you? Your first girlfriend?
Um. Fifteen.
That’s a good age. Did you do it?
Excuse me?
With her? Did you all “get it on”? I'm always asking people when they lost their virginity, I hope you don’t mind.
When did you first have sex?
Far too young.  53.

Well, this girl was a field hockey player, but she didn’t start playing until six months after we started going out. She tried out on a lark: I remember being like, ‘You're gonna do what?’ (beat) We weren’t very sporty the two of us. But she liked it. She went to practice all the time. It is nice to watch girls in skirts beating the hell out of each other on a spring afternoon.
Hot. Idyllic.
And guess what she’s doing now?
Coke.
Oh, nice. No, she’s a cop.
No way.

I'm telling the truth. We used to sit around and smoke pot and she’d talk about wanting to join the FBI. But now she’s really a cop in my hometown. Whenever I go to see my parents I have these fantasies of driving real fast and then getting pulled over and then there she is. Brie looks at him questioningly.
There’s a male fantasy for you. Right there. Positions of authority.
No, it’s not like that. I’d just like to see her again. It’s been... six or so years since I’ve seen her.  54.
What happened?
You mean, why did we break up?
Sure.
We were in tenth grade. We broke up.
You never said if you had sex.
Didn't I? Brie shakes her head.
Huh. Luke finishes off his beer. He smiles.
Party pooper. BRIE (CONT’D) Speaking of. I really should get going.
Oh, right. To meet your friends.
Yeah, it’s my girlfriend’s birthday and I have to at least make an appearance.
Okay.
And I'd better get there before she passes out.
Oh really? She’s one of those girls?  55.
Well, no, she’s not like a drunk or a sorority girl or anything. But when it’s her birthday she'll let herself loose, you know?
Sure.
So. Brie finishes off her drink.
Then I guess I’d better be... Do you want to come along?
What? What?
Oh, to the party?
Yeah.
Go to the party?
Yeah.
Um. Do you think it’1ll be weird, I mean is it just a bunch of good friends?
No, it’1ll be fine.
Okay then. If you think so.
You'll be alright. Brie leads the way as they head out of the bar.
Where is it?
Highland Park kind of.  56.
Luke and Brie walk outside of the bar.
Should I just follow you?
Yes. It’s off Riverside, but just follow me.
Okay. 22 INT. LUKE’S CAR - NIGHT 22 Luke drives and talks on the phone to Colin. He’s wearing glasses.
Dude, I am rubbing two sticks together out here.
Is she flirting with you?
I don’t know. She’s talking to me.
Is she checking her watch all the time though?
No, it’s nothing obvious. She’s just giving me mixed signals, man.
That’s what women do.
I mean, it’s fun but what the fuck am I supposed to do? I suck at dates. Still driving, Luke rummages around in the side panel of car.
Actually, I don’t even know if it is a date. Midway through, she said we should call this girl Leslie because she is on a date. (MORE )
And she kept saying the word, “date”, really casually, like what we were doing was something totally different.
But she invited me to the party, so that’s something right?
Yeah.
I just have no clue.
Listen. You'd rather be out with a girl going to some random party, then over here at my house playing Guitar Hero, right? He pulls out a bowl that’s already half-filled with pot.
I don’t know any of these people.
That’s why you’re perfectly safe, then. They don’t know you. No harm no foul. You can pretty much burn the house down and emerge unscathed.
Yeah. Still driving, and talking on the phone, Luke sparks up.
Is she cool?
Christ. She’s gorgeous. And smart. She’s way smarter than me, man. I’m not trying to cast any undue aspersions here, but she’s sharp as a tack.
See. There you go.  23 24 25 26 58.
And she might be a little mean. I like a woman who could beat me up though.
How’s the rack?
Good. I think. I mean, fine. Wanna hear something weird? (beat) When she smiles I kinda want to break down in tears. That’s weird, right?
No, that’s gay. INT. BRIE’S CAR- SAME TIME 23 Brie drives and occasionally checks her hair and make up the rear view mirror. She also checks on Luke and can see him chatting vivaciou on his phone.

Brie parks but Luke has to drive around a bit more to fin empty spot. Finally he finds one and he parks his car. It has a dent side of the door. It is quite dirty. INT. LUKE’S CAR - NIGHT 25 He puts the car in park and composes himself. He pulls an INHALER out of the same side panel he got the bowl from and takes a big puff. He puts it back in the bo with his glasses. He’s hitting his stride now.
Luke walks up the street towards the sound of the party. Brie stands by the front waiting for him.
You've gotta meet my friend Dickie?  27 59.
Dickie?
Yeah, he’s an amazing writer. Like actually brilliant.
Okay. They walk up to the party, which seems to be taking place much outside of the house as inside it.
CAMERON, a bubbly young female, is doing cartwheels in th yard for a crowd. Luke stops to notice her. Cameron looks up a notices Brie.
Brie! Ahhh! She runs over and hugs Brie.
Hey, happy birthday slut.
Thanks.
This is my friend Luke Putnam. Luke extends his hand.
Hey.
Hi, Luke Putnam.
What’s going on?
Nothing. Come on back. Drink some jack and coke.
Where’s Dickie? Is he here?  28 29 60.

Yeah. He’s somewhere. Brie scampers off and Luke begins to follow but Cameron k him around. CAMERON (CONT’D) Do you want beer? Because the keg is in the back back but we have vodka and whiskey and spooky punch in the kitchen.
Spooky punch?
Yeah, it’s my secret recipe. It’s supposed to be for Halloween but it’ll get you drunk quick so I made some anyway.
Well I want to try some of that. I want to see what’s so spooky about it.
Ok, come on.

Luke walks around, holding a glass of spooky punch. There are people all around, none of whom he knows. Nobody noti him. He sees Brie talking to DICKIE (20s) in the corner of the living room. He opts not to interrupt.
Luke wanders around the house. He watches people warily. inspects the books or whatever happens to be lying around
GAIL and HILARY and IAN are talking about wildlife encounters.
We've got this possum in our yard.  30 EXT. Luke game Brie 61.
Eeek. They’re so scary. Those tails...they’re like giant rats.
I’1ll trade you your possum for my skunk.
No!
I’m not kidding. He’s been in our yard for the last two nights.
You don’t want to fuck with a skunk.
I waved this broom at him. He was crouching over by the fence. He just hissed at me and ran off.
What are you going to do?
He bared his damn teeth at me.
He’s like This is my yard, bitch!

This is terrible. I hit a skunk with my car. Right after I first moved here. He just ran out in the road and I clipped him with like, my back wheel. The trunk of my car almost melted off. I had to drive with the windows down for three days.
is back outside, watching and cheering on strangers in a of beer pong. comes up to Luke, out of the crowd.  62.
So... If Cameron asks you a question, you need to answer yes. Okay?
Um. Okay. What question? What am I answering yes to?
Just if she asks you anything.
I saw her by that bush over there. I think she lost an earring.
She’s fine. She found it.
So the answer is yes?
Yup.
What did you do? Did you do something?
No. I told her we had sex over there (points) And that we did it for five minutes.
Where? (points) In the hammock? Five minutes?
(nodding) It was magical.
I think I can do that.
Now come meet Dickie.  31 63.
In the kitchen, DICKIE (20's) is holding court. GIRLS and guy or two stand around him. Brie makes her way through t room with Luke trailing behind her.

You want to know what the problem is? I stopped reading books. For two weeks now I haven’t read a thing. I haven’t had any time to myself at all. My attention span is fucked. I can’t concentrate, my vocabulary is getting worse... He spots Brie.
Hey again.
I want you to meet my friend Luke.
Hey Luke. They shake hands.
You friends with Cameron?
I just met her out front, actually. She was doing cartwheels.
She should be. You only turn eighteen once, right?
She's eighteen?
No. There would be a lot of people in jail tonight if she was just turning eighteen.
(raising her hand) I’m one of them.
(to Luke) Having fun?  64.
Yeah. I just got here.
I found him on the side of the road. He looked lonely. He told me he was tired from selling his body all the time.
It’s a tough racket.
Those streets are cold, man. Luke expects a laugh that doesn’t come.
Dickie is the most amazing writer.
So I hear. Oh my God...
No he seriously is. You two would get along. You could talk and talk about books.
Are you a writer? LUKE’ BRIE Well, right now I’m working Luke is taking time off. He on... just quit his job to work on a piece.
That's fantastic. So you’re unemployed?
I’m working on my own stuff right now.
What? Journalism? Screenplays? Everybody out here seems to be secreting screenplays.
Yeah, no. I’m working on a long piece for the Los Angeles Times.  65.
Oh, do you know Dean Baquet?
Who?
He’s the Editor-In-Chief. Last time I checked. He’s an amazing man. Just came in from New York and took the reins. Amazing man. They treated him like shit in New York.
I don’t know him. I’m working with Karen Middleton in the Sunday section.
That’s great. One of those big Sunday features.
That’s what I’m hoping for.
(to Luke) Do you know Stanford University?
Sure. I know it. Dickie just finished his fellowship there.
Really? The Graduate Program?
The Stegner.
No way.
They paid his whole way for two years. I told you. He’s a brilliant writer.
(to Brie) Are you trying to hook us up?
I’m just saying!  66.
(to Luke) It was a cool program. Tobias Wolff. Amazing man.
I love his work. I applied there last year but I guess they weren’t having it.
Ah. Fuck ‘em. I mean, you know, the competition is so fucking fierce for what? Like twelve places?
I didn’t apply to the Stegner thing. Just for the journalism department.
Well they’re obviously idiots. Go back to ‘em next year with your Times feature. They’1l be drooling. By that time, you’1ll have done a bunch of work and you won’t even want to bother with school.
(to Brie and Dickie) How long have you guys known each other?
Centuries. What was it? The Boer War?
We used to be roommates. The House of Clothes.
Yeah. What a mess that was. (to Brie) You know I saw Stephanie recently. She made the cover of...Italian Vogue I think? She seemed like she was doing well.
(to Dickie) So you lived with all those models?  32 67.

On and off. They were kind enough to give me a couch for awhile and then Stephanie...she’s the successful one...had to go to Milan or something...so I just subletted her room for what turned out to be the better part of like, a year and a half.
I’m so glad I don’t live there anymore.
Yeah. It was rough. All those models prancing around in their underwear. Pillow-fighting. I swear. It was like something you read about.
I don’t know, it seemed pretty normal at the time.
Not this one though. (points to Brie) In her room with the door shut and her nose in a book.
Ha. Not always.
(smiling) Not always. Dickie and Brie both laugh.
Where’s the bathroom around here? Luke slides away to find the bathroom.
CAMERON finds Luke sitting on the couch, watching people, drinking beer from a red plastic cup.
Putnam.  68.
Yes?
Hi. Cameron sits down on the couch. She makes whoever was sit down get up.
It’s my birthday.
I heard. How old are you?
You’re not supposed to ask a lady her age.
You set me up for it. But if you want to tell somebody your true age, it might as well be me since I don’t know anyone else here.
Guess.
I’m not guessing. That is the road to peril. Cameron leans in to Luke, uncomfortably close. He might s back a bit into the couch.
You have to guess.
You have to tell me. (beat) Here. Whisper it into my ear. Cameron whispers something inaudible in Luke’s ear.
She told you that huh? Cameron nods. Luke grimaces.
That’s nice of her.  69.
I’m just kidding. She didn’t say that. You got kind of surly. That’s cute.
Surly is cute?
Have you played beer battleship?
No, but I saw a bit. I think I might come out there in a minute.
You should. It’s amazing.
Okay.
EDIE and FEROCIOUS stand in a corner. Ferocious is acting out his name on the air guitar.
You look retarded when you play air guitar.
I don’t care. I’m gifted.
No. I mean it. I’m going to punch you in the arm.
Luke and Brie sit outside.
You can mingle if you want.
No, I did. It’s fine.
You don’t have to entertain me.
Good, because I left my spinning plates at home.  Pause. 70.
Whenever I go to parties, I usually just wind up talking with the one person I came with.
Everybody does that.
I usually just sit around and watch people. I’m pretty shy, usually.
You’re not shy. You’re the least shy person I’ve ever met.
No. I am in certain situations. Parties aren’t really my forte.
Well, Cameron likes you.
That's cool. My confidence points are increasing.

head_text.subj: LET'S HEAR IT FOR THE SPACE

text: Maybe if you're lucky, you'll get throw-up on your shoes. Luke They're pretty serious here.
Got a lot of steam to let off.

I know this girl who’s a stand-up comedian. Totally frightening, right? She feeds off getting up at open mic nights and telling jokes, but when you get her in a party atmosphere or regular social situations, she’s just terrified.  71.

Yeah. You’re supposed to get outdoors and meet new people, right? So now I have a compulsion to get out of the house and into new situations. Like maybe there’s a whole echelon of people I’m missing out on being with. I think I'd just like to be better socially adjusted.
I was an insomniac, did I tell you that?
No.

Well, I grew up in this really small town called Dracut and I was too young to have my own car or anything and try to make out to Boston or Lowell or wherever and do fun things. And I had the worst time sleeping. The whole house would be asleep and I couldn’t even get up and walk around or anything because I was afraid of waking up my sister. (She actually smiles a little at the following: ) So I'd sit there and stare at the ceiling and imagine all the fun things that were happening without me.
Were you ever popular?

Yeah. In High School. And college. I mean, you know. I had friends. But I had a real awkward period first. Do you remember when parties used to be the highlight of your week? Or at least they were something that you looked forward to.
Like a county fair in the summer.  72.
Exactly. They were unique. Maybe because we just hadn’t been to so many. They were still a new experience. You know... (eyebrows raised) .--dancing with boys.

Oh God. I hated dancing. (beat) Agh. See, I’m having flashbacks. Luke holds his hands out like a zombie, except that his h are turned like he’s holding a phantom dancer. Brie smile He puts his arms down.

This may sound stupid, but maybe you can help me out with this thought I’ve been having. I worry sometimes that what I’m experiencing won’t be enough. In the long run. That I’m putting all my money in this one bank...or...no...that I’m reading this one newspaper. And then, one day, come to find out that this newspaper is wrong. That it’s been reporting the wrong news. I’ve been reading about things never really happened. Or that happened slightly different than reported.
But if you never find out then it’s all real news to you.
But what happens when the curtain is suddenly pulled back?
Why did you move here?

I don’t know. It rained a lot in Knoxville. We were in the mountains. When I got out here, it hadn’t rained in six months. I thought: this is the place for me for now. But now I just miss the rain. I miss having the option of bad weather.  Pause. 73.
That’s it? You moved out here for the sunshine? That’s pretty generic.
But it’s a good reason. You lived in a small town. You should know. All I ever wanted to do was be somewhere else.
Yeah. I know about that. But you can’t just move for the sake of moving.
I could do stories all over the world.
Do you worry about what people are thinking about?
Worry how? What people are thinking about me?
Sure.
I don’t know that it worries me. But I might get upset if some guy was talking shit about my haircut behind my back. Say, if this guy was my best friend. I might find that a little unsettling.
I worry about people’s priorities.
What do you mean?
Like what do people really want? I’m a secretary. You’re an intern. Cameron is a bartender. We've all been out of college for a while. Our priorities are becoming more streamlined. (MORE )
Why isn’t anybody really going after something and putting us all to shame? I mean, aside from Dickie, who is amazing and driven, I don’t think anyone knows what's next.
I feel like I’m going after something.
I mean, I guess we all are. But not really.
Maybe you aren’t, but don’t lump me in with your slacker friends. Brie looks at Luke for a long second.
You’re twenty-what? Seven? You’re not married. You think you can be single and drift. Write your pieces here and there and do what you want.
And you can’t?

Luke and Brie come back to the spot where they had their fight. Luke is carrying two beers for them and Brie is grabbing cigarettes out of her purse. She hands him a cigarette and lights her own. She lights for him and he hand her a beer. They both exhale a drag in silence.  79.
